div.head: Clarify how to encode short-form citationsÂ #1431
div.p: Bibliography is hard.

The consensus from the ticket seems to favor using bibl with @id to encode your long-form â€œback of the bookâ€ bibliographic entries, and then to use ref and @target to wrap short citations in the text. This isnâ€™t the only type of short-form citation that occurs though. Short-form citations can occur in the absence of a fuller bibliographic reference. Short citations might refer to abstract â€œworksâ€ rather than to specific edition (e.g.Â Hamlet,Â Hom. Il.) or they might refer to a specific edition using a conventional syntax (e.g.Â IG IÂ³ 40). All of these might occur in a text without a â€˜referentâ€™ elsewhere in the text. The suggestion has been made that these kinds of bibliographic references are akin to the kind of nameâ€”named entity relationships that occur with persName and person or placeName and place, and that therefore @ref might profitably be added to bibl to accommodate this kind of relationship. Others argue that @corresp is a satisfactory way to do this. But, perhaps crucially, the referenced entity might not be defined in TEI. <bibl ref=â€http://catalog.perseus.org/catalog/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001â€œ>Hom. Il.</bibl> might be a reasonable thing to do, for example. Others argue that <ref target=â€http://catalog.perseus.org/catalog/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001â€œ>biblHom. Il.</bibl></ref> is the right thing to do. The semantics of @target donâ€™t seem to me to work for this, but we ultimately define those semantics, soâ€¦
Iâ€™ve outlined my understanding of the semantics of the relevant attributes below:

p.hi: @ref encodes the relationship: name refers to <named entity>
@target encodes the relationship: reference points to target
@corresp encodes the relationship: element is aligned with, or defines something related to element

div.head: path should exist alongside zone for non-closed areas in facsimileÂ #1453
div.p: Martin Holmes asked for a @path on zone to express things in images (especially maps) that arenâ€™t boxes (roads, river courses, etc.). We said zone has area, and therefore @path wouldnâ€™t make sense. Martin then asked for path (based on Councilâ€™s feedback). We werenâ€™t happy with that either. This hits right at the heart of where the boundaries of TEI are. Should we add path? Should we back off from implementing our own version of SVG, but allow @path on zone?Â [Note: Iâ€™m in favor of something like this that allows @path or path, with this understanding: TEI isnâ€™t doing the drawing in the coordinate system, but it provides storage of needed descriptive information, which can later be readily processed by transformation into SVG (or KML, etc).Apologies if this is a bad analogy, but we store URLs in TEI that are not activated as â€œhyperlinksâ€ until they are transformed or translated into something readable by a web browser. The function of the TEI here seems to be to hold text-encoded data that describes and can helpfully be processed and translated into other formats.]Should we allow neither? Should we recommend using SVG and specify how?
